item.title: AirAsia and AirAsia X introduce an innovative inflight menu concept
item.description: Source: AirAsia. AirAsia and AirAsia X have introduced “Santan,” a new in-flight menu, replacing “AirAsia Café.” This change aims to elevate the airline group’s image and provide travelers with a more sophisticated culinary experience. Passengers can now purchase or pre-order new menu items, including nasi dagang and chicken curry, a Malaysian dish from the East Coast. Additional on-board purchases on AirAsia flights include teriyaki chicken rice cake and smoked chicken pizza sandwiches.

item.title: AirAsia X will provide a connection between Kuala Lumpur and Auckland
item.description: Source: AirAsia. AirAsia X launches flights from Kuala Lumpur to Auckland. AirAsia X, the long-haul, budget-friendly part of the AirAsia Group, is starting flights to Auckland, New Zealand, from Kuala Lumpur. The route will have a stopover on the Gold Coast of Australia and begins on March 22, 2016. Benyamin Ismail, CEO of AirAsia X, stated that New Zealand is a top-tier destination that the company has always valued. He expressed excitement about returning to the country and offering this new service.

item.title: New e-book series examines generational disparities in the workplace
item.description: The INSEAD Emerging Markets Institute collaborated with employer branding specialist Universum, Singapore-based think tank The HEAD Foundation, and MIT Leadership Centre to release Brave New Workplace, the first in a series of e-books called Generations Series. As companies aim to create optimal work environments and policies for multigenerational workforces, they may find generational differences to be a significant factor, though this is not always the case. Brave New Workplace examines how Gen X, Gen Y, and Gen Z are transforming the nature of work and workplace culture by looking at their behaviors and attitudes.

item.title: Many Singaporeans are aware of human trafficking but underestimate its prevalence
item.description: The International Organization for Migration’s X Campaign (IOM X), in collaboration with USAID, the US Embassy in Singapore, and Microsoft, recently released findings from their pilot outreach program, IOM X Connect Singapore. This initiative sought to increase awareness about human trafficking in Singapore. During the project, students from the National University of Singapore (NUS) and Singapore Management University (SMU) utilized the newly developed IOM X Learn, Act and Share App. They tested the knowledge of 100 Singaporean residents on the topic of human trafficking.
